{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Use British English|date=October 2011}} [[Image:COLKIWI.jpg|thumb|Colin Skinner holding a year old [[kiwi]]]]
Dr. '''Colin Skinner''' (born 1965) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] author, adventurer and [[molecular biology|molecular biologist]] who is attempting to walk around the world. As of mid-2014, he has walked over {{convert|14500|mi|km}} and has crossed [[Great Britain]], [[Iceland]], [[United States|America]] and [[New Zealand]].<ref name="Meet Doctor Colin Skinner">{{cite web|url=http://teacher.scholastic.com/zealand/meet.htm |title=Meet Doctor Colin Skinner |publisher=Teacher.scholastic.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref> He has used the walks to raise money and awareness for various causes, including [[conservation biology]], people with [[disabilities]], cancer relief, [[AIDS]], and [[hospice]].
==Education== Skinner earned his [[Bachelor of Science]] (B.Sc.) combined honours degree in [[biochemistry]] and [[genetics]] from the [[University of Leeds]]. He earned his [[PhD]] in [[molecular biology]] from [[University College London]]. He earned his [[Postgraduate Certificate in Education]] (PGCE) in secondary science from [[Canterbury Christ Church University]].
==Walking around the world==
===Scotland to England in 1984=== He began at the age of 18 at [[John o' Groats]] (at the northern tip of [[Scotland]]) in 1984, and walked to [[Land's End]] in [[England]]. On this journey, which he carried out with three other people, he pushed a wheelchair {{convert|1000|mi|km}} and raised £3,500 for The Forelands School for handicapped children. In 1983, he had already run {{convert|21|mi|km}} around a 400-metre track to raise further money for The Forelands School for handicapped children, at [[Broadstairs]] in [[Kent]].
===Iceland in 1986=== In 1986, at the age of 20, whilst at the University of Leeds, he crossed [[Iceland]], together with three other people, from [[Seyðisfjörður]] in the east, through the interior to the north of the [[Vatnajökull]] ice fields, and then west to [[Reykjavík]]. The team encountered an 'ash storm', where storm force winds had whipped up fine black [[volcanic ash]], and had to wear goggles and face masks to push on into the winds. In the [[rain shadow]] of the [[Vatnajökull]], they ran out of water, then encountered a flash flood, as mud rushed down from the melting [[glaciers]]. They also had to survive on food contaminated with [[petrol]] that had leaked from their [[petrol]] stoves. This journey of {{convert|400|mi|km}} raised £2,000 for the Royal Association for Disability and Rehabilitation. As part of the training for the walk across Iceland he ran the Leeds Marathon, in a time of 3 hours and 41 minutes.
On the Icelandic trek, he came up with the idea of walking {{convert|6000|mi|km}}, across Britain and America to raise money for [[Macmillan Cancer Support]] in Britain and [[Hospice care|hospice]] in America and [[Canada]].
===Scotland to England in 1988=== On 1 May 1988, he set off again from [[John o' Groats]], this time walking through the [[West Highlands]], down the [[Pennine Way]] and then south to [[Land's End]]: a distance of {{convert|1100|mi|km}} in seven weeks. As part of the training for this walk he ran the gruelling [[Snowdonia Marathon]], in a time of 4 hours and 40 minutes. The walk through Scotland and England raised £2,000 for [[Macmillan Cancer Support]].<ref>''Taking a walk across America,'' [[East Kent Mercury and Dover Mercury|East Kent Mercury]], 7 July 1988</ref>
===Across the U.S.A. in 1988/1989=== [[Image:TETON7.JPG|thumb|left|Colin Skinner walking by the [[Teton Mountains]]]]
The journey across the [[United States]] began on 15 July 1988. On the journey he slept in bushes beneath the [[World Trade Center (1973-2001)|World Trade Center]], camped outside [[Kennedy Airport]] in a tent, then headed west. On [[Staten Island]] he collapsed from heat exhaustion at 105 degrees [[Fahrenheit]]. In [[Utah]] the temperatures went down to minus 30 [[Fahrenheit]]. Carrying a tent and a backpack, with no backup, he walked alone to [[Niagara Falls]], through [[Ontario]] in [[Canada]], to [[Detroit]], between the [[Great Lakes]], across the [[Great Plains]], through the [[Rocky Mountains|Rockies]] in winter, to [[Yellowstone National Park]], then south to the [[Grand Canyon]], on to [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], through [[Death Valley]] and then snowshoed over the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierras]] to reach [[San Francisco]]. In Death Valley, down to his last $13, Skinner found $200 in the desert, and he had $1 left when he crossed the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierras]] to reach [[Yosemite]] Valley. The total distance he walked from [[New York City]] to [[San Francisco]], was {{convert|4952|mi|km}}.<ref>''Scotland to S.F. 6,000-Mile Hike for Hospices'' San Francisco Chronicle, 22 March 1989</ref>
On the journey he visited 70 hospices and appeared on television, radio and in newspapers to encourage support for hospices across the U.S. and [[Canada]]. The mayor of [[San Francisco]], [[Art Agnos]], proclaimed 21 March 1989, "Colin Skinner Day," in recognition of the attention he brought to the work of hospices with [[AIDS]] patients in the city.
Returning to [[United Kingdom|Britain]] after this walk, he obtained a job as a research assistant in Chemical [[Pathology]] at the [[Middlesex Hospital]] and went on to obtain a [[PhD]] in [[Molecular Biology]] at [[University College London]]. In 1992, whilst studying for his PhD, he also ran the [[London Marathon]], in a time of 4 hours and 41 minutes, to raise money to buy a computer for a young boy with physical disabilities. Skinner's PhD involved developing genetic tests to detect [[congenital adrenal hyperplasia]] in children.<ref>Rumsby, G., Skinner, C., Lee, H.A. & Honour, J.W. (1992). Combined 17α-hydroxylase/ 17,20 lyase deficiency caused by heterozygous stop codons in the cytochrome P450 17α-hydroxylase gene. ''Clin. Endocrinol.'' '''39''':483-485.</ref> He had work published in a number of scientific journals.<ref>Rumsby, G., Skinner, C. and Honour, J.W. (1992). Genetic analysis of the steroid 21-hydroxylase gene following ''in vitro'' amplification of genomic DNA. ''J. Steroid. Biochem.'' '''41''':827-829.</ref> In 1994 he had his work published in ''Human Molecular Genetics''.<ref>Skinner, C.A. & Rumsby, G. (1994). Steroid 11β-hydroxylase deficiency caused by a five base pair duplication in the ''CYP11B1'' gene. ''Hum. Mol. Genet.'' '''3''':377-378.</ref>
In 1994, Skinner married Dr. Monica Schneider (also a molecular biologist), and in 1996 their son James was born. From 1994 to 1996 Skinner worked as a Post-Doctoral Research Fellow at [[Vanderbilt University Medical Center]], in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], [[Tennessee]].<ref>Keeney D.S., Skinner C., Travers J.B., Capdevila J.H., Nanney L.B., King L.E. Jr., Waterman M.R.(1998). Differentiating keratinocytes express a novel cytochrome P450 enzyme, CYP2B19, having arachidonate monooxygenase activity. ''J. Biol. Chem.'' 273 '''48''':32071-32079.</ref> The work he carried out there involved [[DNA sequencing|gene sequencing]] and [[protein purification]] of [[cytochrome P450]] enzymes. His work was published in the ''Journal of Biological Chemistry''.<ref>Keeney D.S., Skinner C., Wei S., Friedberg T., Waterman M.R. (1998). A keratinocyte-specific epoxygenase, CYP2B12, metabolizes [[arachidonic acid]] with unusual selectivity producing a single major epoxyeicosatrienoic acid. ''J. Biol. Chem.'' 273 '''15''':9279-9284</ref> From 1996 to 1997 Skinner took care of his infant son, James, whilst his wife continued to work at [[Vanderbilt University Medical Center]].
===New Zealand in 1998=== In 1998 he walked from [[Cape Reinga]] in the North Island, to [[Bluff, New Zealand|Bluff]], at the southern tip of [[New Zealand]]; a distance of {{convert|1500|mi|km}}. On the journey he walked through the active [[volcano]] at [[Whakaari/White Island|White Island]], experienced earthquakes up to 4.9 on the [[Richter Scale]], clambered over [[glaciers]], swam with [[pinniped|seals]] and reported on [[conservation biology]] projects involving [[endangered species]]. Information from the journey was posted on the [[Internet]] for schoolchildren in the U.S. via the [[Scholastic Corporation]] Scholastic Network.<ref name="Meet Doctor Colin Skinner"/> In December 2010 Skinner completed a book about the journey and [[conservation biology]], ''New Zealand - 1500 miles on foot through - The Land Of The Long White Cloud'' on an [[Internet]] website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wattpad.com/story/2098040-new-zealand |title=New Zealand 1500 miles on foot through The Land Of The Long White Cloud |publisher=Wattpad |date=2012-09-09 |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref>
In 1999 he obtained a [[Postgraduate Certificate in Education|PGCE]] (Postgraduate Certificate in Education) from [[Canterbury Christ Church University]] in [[Canterbury]], England. In 2000 he worked as a secondary school science teacher at St. Edmund's School in [[Dover]], teaching 11 to 16-year-olds.<ref>''What is it about teaching that's enticing so many of us Back to School?'' The Sunday Express Magazine, 7 November 1999</ref>
In 2001 he worked as a volunteer at a wildlife park, working on enrichment activities for animals. From 2001 until 2003 he worked part-time at a [[post office]]. During this time, he also taught science to primary school children, in a 'Link-Scientist' scheme run by the pharmaceutical company [[Pfizer]], and took care of his son.
In 2003 his mother died from [[pancreatic cancer]], at the age of 59. This prompted him to write the story of the {{convert|6000|mi|km}} journey across [[Great Britain|Britain]] and America. In 2006 he finished the book ''Beyond the Setting Sun'', with an introduction by [[Ranulph Fiennes]], the renowned polar explorer and adventurer.<ref>[http://www.freewebs.com/drskinnersite/ranulphfiennesview.htm Dr. Colin Skinner's Site | Walking 6000 miles for hospice<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The book was written to raise money for hospices in [[United Kingdom|Britain]], [[Canada]] and America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wattpad.com/story/2094649-beyond-the-setting-sun |title=Beyond the Setting Sun |publisher=Wattpad |date=2012-09-09 |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref>
===Scotland to England in 2007=== On 29 April 2007, he began walking again at [[John o' Groats]] and arrived at [[Land's End]] on 8 June, having covered {{convert|900|mi|km}} in 6 weeks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisiscornwall.co.uk/ |title=news, entertainment, jobs, homes and cars |publisher=this is cornwall |date= |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref> On the walk in Britain he visited 20 hospices and raised £10,000 for hospice through sales of his ''Beyond the Setting Sun'' book.
===U.S.A. in 2009=== [[Image:Colin Skinner in 2009.jpg|thumb|left|Colin Skinner wearing a [[Balaclava (clothing)|balaclava]] during snow storm in [[North Dakota]]]]
Starting on 22 August 2009, he walked from [[Kennedy Airport]] in [[New York City]] to within 15 miles of [[Devils Lake, North Dakota|Devil's Lake]], [[North Dakota]]. This was a distance of {{convert|2053|mi|km}} and Skinner stopped his journey on 3 December 2009, after 3 days with windchills down to -30 [[Fahrenheit]]. During the trip Skinner had to make incisions in his feet to relieve the [[pressure]] from [[blisters]], suffered [[food poisoning]], met up with a [[wolf]] in [[Upper Peninsula of Michigan|Upper Michigan]], had to face down two wild dogs, and had [[ski masks]] frozen to his beard in [[North Dakota]]. On the journey he appeared on television, radio and in newspaper articles.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mlive.com/news/bay-city/index.ssf/2009/10dr_colin_skinner_stops_at_bria.html |title=MLive.com |publisher=MLive.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808063001/http://www.mlive.com/news/bay-city/index.ssf/2009/10dr_colin_skinner_stops_at_bria.html |archivedate=8 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He also wrote a daily blog for the National Hospice Foundation.<ref name="nationalhospicefoundation.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalhospicefoundation.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageID=368 |title=Colin Skinner Is Walking—and Blogging—from NYC to Minot, ND to Raise Awareness of Hospice |publisher=National Hospice Foundation |date=2009-08-21 |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref> He met [[hospice]] patients, including one woman with a terminal illness, who said that at times she could forget she was ill, thanks to the care she received in a [[hospice]] house in [[Buffalo, New York]]. He also met a man with [[lung cancer]] who could not sleep in hospitals, where there was always someone coming to check on him. In the [[hospice]] house in [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]], [[Ontario]], the man had a peaceful room to himself, where he could finally get some rest.<ref name="nationalhospicefoundation.org"/>
===U.S.A. in 2011=== On 10 September 2011, Skinner set off from mile marker 283 on [[U.S. Route 2]], {{convert|15|mi|km}} before [[Devils Lake, North Dakota|Devil's Lake]], [[North Dakota]] and walked {{convert|2576|mi|km}} to [[Tuolumne Meadows]] in [[Yosemite National Park]], [[California]]. The walk took him through [[North Dakota]], [[Montana]], [[Idaho]], [[Utah]], [[Arizona]], [[Nevada]] and into [[California]]. Skinner snow-shoed over [[Tioga Pass]] and camped in a tent in the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Mountains]] for several nights,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thesheetnews.com/archives/12352 |title=Archives | The Sheet - Part 12352 |publisher=Thesheetnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref> but was forced to stop walking after suffering from [[frostbite]] in both feet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mammothtimes.com/content/walking-dying-hiker-stares-death-eye |title=Walking for the dying, hiker stares death in the eye |publisher=Mammoth Times |date=2012-02-03 |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref> On the journey he appeared on television, radio and in newspapers and encouraged support for [[hospices]] taking care of people with serious illnesses.<ref name="nationalhospicefoundation.org2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalhospicefoundation.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageID=604 |title=Walking Across North America for Hospice |publisher=National Hospice Foundation |date= |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref> Skinner is now writing a book about this journey, entitled ''America- 12000 miles on foot, a wing and a prayer''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clipsyndicate.com/video/play/3151738/helping_hospice_brown_mon_01_02_2012 |title=Clip Syndicate Video: HELPING HOSPICE | Brown | MON 01/02/2012 |publisher=Clipsyndicate.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref>
In September 2012, Skinner completed a short story, entitled ''Chenga'', and published this on an [[Internet]] website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wattpad.com/story/2109001-chenga |title=Chenga |publisher=Wattpad |date=2012-09-09 |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref> In October 2012, Skinner completed the second part of a [[science-fiction]] [[fantasy]] [[trilogy]], entitled ''Djara'', and published this on an [[Internet]] website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wattpad.com/story/2174701-djara |title=Djara |publisher=Wattpad |date=2012-09-09 |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref>
Skinner has now begun writing the third part of the [[science-fiction]] [[fantasy]] [[trilogy]], entitled ''Tau''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wattpad.com/story/2175992-tau |title=Tau |publisher=Wattpad |date=2012-09-09 |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref> The ''Chenga'', ''Djara'', ''Tau'' [[trilogy]] includes the themes of [[time travel]], [[Parallel universe (fiction)|parallel universes]], [[vampires]], shapeshifters, [[angels]], [[demons]] and descendants of the fabled [[Giant (mythology)|giants]] known as the [[Nephilim]].
In 2012 Skinner published four short poems: ''Gaia'', ''The Dreaming'', ''New Zealand Water Torture'' and ''Life Jim But Not As We Know It'' on an [[Internet]] website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wattpad.com/7554587-gaia |title=Gaia |publisher=Wattpad |date=2012-09-26 |accessdate=2014-07-30}}</ref>
He is planning future walks through [[Australia]], [[Japan]], [[China]], [[Tibet]], [[Afghanistan]], [[Iran]], [[Iraq]], [[Israel]], [[Egypt]] and [[Europe]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==Books== *''Beyond the Setting Sun - 6000 miles on foot for hospice.'' {{ISBN|1-4276-0913-6}} *''New Zealand - 1500 miles on foot through the Land Of The Long White Cloud.'' {{ISBN|978-1-4276-2089-7}}

{{Mesopotamian myth (7)}}
The '''Debate between Winter and Summer''' or '''Myth of Emesh and Enten''' is a [[Sumerian language|Sumerian]] [[creation myth]], written on [[clay tablet]]s in the mid to late 3rd millennium [[Anno Domini|BC]].<ref name="Walton2009">{{cite book|author=John H. Walton|title=The Lost World of Genesis One: Ancient Cosmology and the Origins Debate|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6qZLAz3TckgC&pg=PA34|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=30 July 2009|publisher=InterVarsity Press|isbn=978-0-8308-3704-5|pages=34–}}</ref>
==Disputations==
Seven "debate" topics are known from the Sumerian literature, falling in the category of '[[disputation]]s'; some examples are: the [[debate between sheep and grain]]; the [[debate between bird and fish]]; the [[debate between tree and the reed|tree and the reed]]; and the [[dispute between silver and copper]], etc.<ref name="Kramer1964">{{cite book|author=Samuel Noah Kramer|title=The Sumerians: their history, culture and character|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iY9xp4pLp88C&pg=PA220|accessdate=23 May 2011|year=1964|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-45238-8|pages=218–}}</ref> These topics came some centuries after writing was established in Sumerian [[Mesopotamia]]. The debates are [[philosophy|philosophical]] and address humanity's place in the world.
==Compilation==
The first lines of the [[myth]] were discovered on the [[University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology]], catalogue of the [[Akkadian language|Babylonian]] section (CBS), tablet number 8310 from their excavations at the [[temple]] [[library]] at [[Nippur]]. This was translated by [[George Aaron Barton]] in 1918 and first published as ''"Sumerian religious texts"'' in ''"[[Miscellaneous Babylonian Inscriptions]]"'', number seven, entitled '''"A Hymn to [[Ibbi-Sin]]"'''.<ref name="Barton1918">{{cite book|author=George Aaron Barton|title=Miscellaneous Babylonian inscriptions, p. 52|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nn5hAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=23 May 2011|year=1918|publisher=Yale University Press}}</ref> The tablet is {{convert|5.5|in|cm}} by {{convert|4.75|in|cm}} by {{convert|1.6|in|cm}} at its thickest point. Barton describes Ibbi-Sin as an ''"inglorious King"'' suggesting the text to have been composed during his lifetime, he commented ''"The hymn provides a powerful statement for emperor worship in Ur at the time of composition."'' Ibbi-Sin is still mentioned in the modern translation ''"For my king named by Nanna, the son of Enlil, Ibbi-Sin, when he is arrayed in the 'cutur' garment and the '[[hursag]]' garment."''<ref name="ETCSL"/>
Another tablet from the same collection, number 8886 was documented by [[Edward Chiera]] in ''"Sumerian Epics and Myths"'', number 46.<ref name="Chiera1964">{{cite book|author=Edward Chiera|title=Sumerian epics and myths, 46|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nEFCPgAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|year=1964|publisher=The University of Chicago Press}}</ref> [[Samuel Noah Kramer]] included CBS tablets 3167, 10431, 13857, 29.13.464, 29.16.142 (which forms a join with 8310), 29.16.232, 29.16.417, 29.16.427, 29.16.446 and 29.16.448. He also included translations from tablets in the Nippur collection of the [[Istanbul Archaeology Museums|Museum of the Ancient Orient]] in [[Istanbul]], catalogue numbers 2705, 3167 and 4004.<ref name="Kramer1944">{{cite book|author=Samuel Noah Kramer|title=Sumerian literary texts from Nippur: in the Museum of the Ancient Orient at Istanbul|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hqdIGQAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|year=1944|publisher=American Schools of Oriental Research}}</ref><ref name="CigKizilyay1969">{{cite book|author1=Muazzez Cig|author2=Hatice Kizilyay|title=Sumerian literary tablets and fragments in the archeological museum of Istanbul-I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vrEnGwAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|year=1969|publisher=Tarih Kurumu Basimevi}}</ref> Further tablets from Nippur were added by Jane Heimerdinger.<ref name="Heimerdinger1979">{{cite book|author=Jane W. Heimerdinger|title=Sumerian literary fragments from Nippur, numbers 55 & 56|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FAKAQgAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=June 1979|publisher=distributed by the Babylonian Fund, University Museum|isbn=978-0-934718-31-8}}</ref> Other tablets were added from the ''"Ur excavations texts"'' in 1928 along with several others to bring it to its present form.<ref name="Mesopotamiamuseum1928">{{cite book|author1=British museum and Pennsylvania University. University museum. Joint expedition to Mesopotamia|author2=Pennsylvania University. University museum|title=Ur excavations texts... 6 36 and 6 37|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4GF1QwAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|year=1928|publisher=British museum}}</ref> A later edition of the text were published by Miguel Civil in 1996.<ref>[http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk/section5/b533.htm The debate between Winter and Summer – Bibliography – The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature, Oxford 1998–.]</ref><ref name="Løkkegaard1990">{{cite book|author=Frede Løkkegaard|title=Bendt Alster., "Sumerian literary dialogues and debates and their Place in Ancient Near East Literature" in Living waters: Scandinavian orientalistic studies presented to Frede Løkkegaard on his seventy-fifth birthday, January 27th 1990|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sY1dVCUIAokC&pg=PA1|accessdate=28 May 2011|year=1990|publisher=Museum Tusculanum Press|isbn=978-87-7289-083-8|pages=1–}}</ref>
==Story==
The story takes the form of a contest poem between two cultural entities first identified by Kramer as [[vegetation]] gods, [[Emesh]] and [[Enten]]. These were later identified with the natural phenomena of [[Winter]] and [[Summer]].<ref name="Løkkegaard1990"/> The location and occasion of the story is described in the introduction with the usual creation sequence of day and night, food and fertility, weather and seasons and [[sluice gate]]s for [[irrigation]].<ref name="Walton2009"/>
{{cquote|''"[[Anu|An]] lifted his head in pride and brought forth a good day. He laid plans for ... and spread the population wide. [[Enlil]] set his foot upon the earth like a great [[bull]]. Enlil, the [[king]] of all lands, set his mind to increasing the good day of abundance, to making the ... night resplendent in celebration, to making [[flax]] grow, to making [[barley]] proliferate, to guaranteeing the spring floods at the quay, to making ... lengthen (?) their days in abundance, to making Summer close the sluices of heaven, and to making Winter guarantee plentiful water at the [[quay]]."''<ref name="Walton2009"/>}}
The two seasons are personified as brothers, born after Enlil [[copulate]]s with a "[[hursag]]" (hill). The destinies of Summer and Winter are then described, Summer founding towns and villages with plentiful harvests, Winter to bring the Spring floods.
{{cquote|''"He copulated with the great hills, he gave the mountain its share. He filled its womb with Summer and Winter, the plenitude and life of the Land. As Enlil copulated with the earth, there was a roar like a bull's. The hill spent the day at that place and at night she opened her loins. She bore Summer and Winter as smoothly as fine oil. He fed them pure plants on the terraces of the hills like great bulls. He nourished them in the pastures of the hills. Enlil set about determining the destinies of Summer and Winter. For Summer founding towns and villages, bringing in harvests of plenitude for the Great Mountain Enlil, sending labourers out to the large arable tracts, and working the fields with oxen; for Winter plenitude, the spring floods, the abundance and life of the Land, placing grain in the fields and fruitful acres, and gathering in everything – Enlil determined these as the destinies of Summer and Winter."''<ref name="ETCSL">[http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk/section5/tr533.htm The debate between Winter and Summer., Black, J.A., Cunningham, G., Robson, E., and Zólyomi, G., The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature, Oxford 1998–.]</ref>}}
The two brothers soon decide to take their gifts to [[Enlil]]'s "house of life", the [[E-namtila]], where they begin a debate about their relative merits. Summer argues:
{{cquote|''"Your straw bundles are for the oven-side, hearth and kiln. Like a herdsman or shepherd encumbered by sheep and lambs, helpless people run like sheep from oven-side to kiln, and from kiln to oven-side, in the face of you. In sunshine ...... you reach decisions, but now in the city people's teeth chatter because of you.<ref name="ETCSL"/>}}
To which Winter replies:
{{cquote|''"Father Enlil, you gave me control of [[irrigation]]; you brought plentiful [[water]]. I made one [[meadow]] adjacent to another and I heaped high the [[granaries]]. The grain became thick in the furrows ... Summer, a bragging field-administrator who does not know the extent of the field, ... my thighs grown tired from toil. ... tribute has been produced for the king's [[palace]]. Winter admires the heart of your ... in words."''<ref name="ETCSL"/>}}
Enlil eventually intervenes and declares Winter the winner of the debate and there is a scene of [[Conflict resolution|reconciliation]]. Bendt Alster explains ''"Winter prevails over Summer, because Winter provides the water that was so essential to agriculture in the hot climate of ancient [[Mesopotamia]]."''<ref name="Løkkegaard1990"/>
{{cquote|''"Enlil answered Summer and Winter: "Winter is controller of the life-giving waters of all the lands – the farmer of the gods produces everything. Summer, my son, how can you compare yourself to your brother Winter?" The import of the exalted word Enlil speaks is artfully wrought, the verdict he pronounces is one which cannot be altered – who can change it? Summer bowed to Winter and offered him a prayer. In his house he prepared [[emmer]]-[[beer]] and [[wine]]. At its side they spend the day at a succulent [[banquet]]. Summer presents Winter with [[gold]], [[silver]] and [[lapis lazuli]]. They pour out brotherhood and friendship like best [[oil]]. By bringing sweet words to the quarrel (?) they have achieved harmony with each other. In the dispute between Summer and Winter, Winter, the faithful farmer of Enlil, was superior to Summer – praise be to the Great [[Mountain]], father Enlil!"''<ref name="ETCSL"/>}}
==Discussion==
John Walton wrote that ''"people in the Ancient Near East did not think of creation in terms of making material things – instead, everything is function oriented. Creation thus constituted bringing order to the cosmos from an originally nonfunctional condition. Consequently, to create something (cause it to exist) in the ancient world means to give it a function, not material properties."''<ref name="Walton2009"/> [[Samuel Noah Kramer]] has noted this myth ''"is the closest extant Sumerian parallel to the Biblical [[Cain and Abel]] story"'' in the [[Book of Genesis]] ({{Bibleverse||Genesis|4:1–16|HE}}).<ref name="Kramer1961">{{cite book|author=Samuel Noah Kramer|title=Sumerian mythology: a study of spiritual and literary achievement in the third millennium B.C.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t16tDOHZLLEC&pg=PA72|accessdate=9 June 2011|year=1961|publisher=Forgotten Books|isbn=978-1-60506-049-1|pages=72–}}</ref> This connection has been made by other scholars.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} The disputation form has also been suggested to have similar elements to the discussions between [[Job (biblical figure)|Job]] and his friends in the [[Book of Job]].<ref name="Perdue1991">{{cite book|author=Leo G. Perdue|title=Wisdom in revolt: metaphorical theology in the Book of Job|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d_KDSNlwvRYC&pg=PA79|accessdate=29 May 2011|year=1991|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-85075-283-7|pages=79–}}</ref> M. L. West noted similarities with [[Aesop]]'s fable "a debate between Winter and Spring" along with another similar work by [[Bion of Smyrna]].<ref name="ClassicsUniversity1969">{{cite book|author1=Harvard University Department of Classics|author2=Department Of Classics Harvard University|title=Harvard Studies in Classical Philology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ih-HfTVGYJoC&pg=PA120|accessdate=29 May 2011|date=1 January 1969|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-37919-0|pages=120–}}</ref>
J.J.A. van Dijk analysed the myth and determined the following common elements with other Sumerian debates ''"(1) Introduction, presenting the disputants and the occasion of the dispute; (2) the dispute itself, in which each party praises himself and attacks the other; (3) judgement uttered by a god, followed by reconciliation; (4) a formula of praise."''<ref name="Dijk1953">{{cite book|author=J. J. A. van Dijk|title=La sagesse suméro-accadienne: recherches sur les genres littéraires des textes sapientiaux, pp. 29–85|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F3MUSwAACAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|year=1953|publisher=E.J. Brill}}</ref><ref name="Murray2006">{{cite book|author=Robert Murray|title=Symbols of church and kingdom: a study in early Syriac tradition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ONJlu1EgVKsC&pg=PA339|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=10 February 2006|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-567-03082-5|pages=339–}}</ref> Bendt Alster suggests a link to [[harvest festival]]s, saying ''"It is definitely conceivable that summer and winter contests may have belonged to festivals celebrating the harvest among the peasants."''<ref name="Løkkegaard1990"/> Herman Vanstiphout has suggested the lexical listing of offerings was used in scribal training, quoting the example from the myth ''"Wild Animals, cattle and sheep from the mountains, Wild rams, mountain rams, deer and full-grown ibex, Mountain sheep, first class sheep, and fat tailed sheep he brings."''<ref name="ReininkVanstiphout1991">{{cite book|author1=G. J. Reinink|author2=Herman L. J. Vanstiphout|title=Dispute poems and dialogues in the ancient and mediaeval Near East: forms and types of literary debates in Semitic and related literatures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YaDpJXhI5j8C&pg=PA42|accessdate=29 May 2011|year=1991|publisher=Peeters Publishers|isbn=978-90-6831-341-3|pages=42–}}</ref>
Eliade and Adams note that in the story, the water flows through the "hursag" (foothills), Enlil is identified as a "[[kurgal]]" (mountain) and his main temple being the "[[eKur]]" (mountain house), they link this mountain aspect with Enlil being the "Lord of the winds" by suggesting the ancients believed the winds originated in the mountains.<ref name="EliadeAdams1987">{{cite book|author1=Mircea Eliade|author2=Charles J. Adams|title=The Encyclopedia of religion|page=454|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7sUkAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=29 May 2011|year=1987|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-02-909800-4}}</ref> Piotr Michalowski makes the connection in the story that "[[E-hursag]]" is a structure ''"named as the residence of the king"'' and "E-namtilla" ''"as the residence of Enlil"'', suspecting the two words refer to the same place and that ''"E-namtilla is simply another name for E-hursag"'' and that it was a [[royal palace]].<ref name="Michalowski1989">{{cite book|author=Piotr Michalowski|title=The lamentation over the destruction of Sumer and Ur|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=te_g2xGYIFEC&pg=PA81|accessdate=29 May 2011|year=1989|publisher=Eisenbrauns|isbn=978-0-931464-43-0|pages=81–}}</ref>

C. Individual Focus. 5. Disputations", in Hallo, William W. {{DEFAULTSORT:Debate Between Summer And Winter}} [[Category:Sumerian disputations]] [[Category:Clay tablets]] [[Category:Mesopotamian mythology]] [[Category:Mythological mountains]] [[Category:Creation myths]] [[Category:Mythological cosmologies]] [[Category:Comparative mythology]]

{{about|a scheme for harvesting electric power from nuclear fusion|the direct energy conversion of a plasma (partially or fully ionized gas) without fusion reactions|MHD generator}}
'''Direct energy conversion''' (DEC) or simply '''direct conversion''' converts a charged particle's [[kinetic energy]] into a [[voltage]]. It is a scheme for power extraction from [[nuclear fusion]].
[[File:Direct Converter.jpeg|thumbnail|A basic direct converter]]
== History and theoretical underpinnings ==
=== Electrostatic direct collectors ===
In the middle of the 1960s direct energy conversion was proposed as a method for capturing the energy from the exhaust gas in a [[fusion reactor]]. This would generate a [[direct current]] of electricity. [[Richard F. Post]] at the [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]] was an early proponent of the idea.<ref name="Post 1969 (a)">{{Cite journal |last=Post |first=Richard F. |title=Direct Conversion of Thermal Energy of High Temperature Plasma |date=November 1969 |journal=Bulletin of the American Physical Society |volume=14 |issue=11 |page=1052}}</ref> Post reasoned that capturing the energy would require five steps:<ref name="Post 1969 (b)">{{Cite conference |last=Post |first=Richard F. |title=Mirror Systems: Fuel Cycles, Loss Reduction and Energy Recovery |conference=BNES Nuclear Fusion Reactor Conference |date=September 1969 |location=Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Oxfordshire, U.K. |publisher=British Nuclear Energy Society |pages=87–111 |url=http://www.askmar.com/Fusion_files/Mirror%20Systems.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref> (1) Ordering the charged particles into linear beam. (2) Separation of positives and negatives. (3) Separating the ions into groups, by their energy. (4) Gathering these ions as they touch collectors. (5) Using these collectors as the positive side in a circuit. Post argued that the efficiency was theoretically determined by the number of collectors.
====The Venetian blind==== Designs in the early 1970s by William Barr and Ralph Moir used metal ribbons at an angle to collect these ions. This was called the Venetian Blind design, because the ribbons look like [[window blinds]]. Those metal ribbon-like surfaces are more transparent to ions going forward than to ions going backward. Ions pass through surfaces of successively increasing potential until they turn and start back, along a [[parabolic trajectory]]. They then see opaque surfaces and are caught. Thus ions are sorted by energy with high-energy ions being caught on high-potential electrodes.<ref name="Moir 1973">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1088/0029-5515/13/1/005| title = "Venetian-blind" direct energy converter for fusion reactors| journal = Nuclear Fusion| volume = 13| pages = 35| year = 1973| last1 = Moir | first1 = R. W. | last2 = Barr | first2 = W. L. | url = http://www.askmar.com/Fusion_files/Venetian%20Blind.pdf| format = PDF}}</ref><ref name="Moir 1974 (a)">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1109/TPS.1974.6593737| title = A preliminary engineering design of a "Venetian blind" direct energy converter for fusion reactors| journal = IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science| volume = 2| issue = 2| pages = 71| year = 1974| last1 = Barr | first1 = W. L.| last2 = Burleigh | first2 = R. J.| last3 = Dexter | first3 = W. L.| last4 = Moir | first4 = R. W.| last5 = Smith | first5 = R. R.| url = http://www.askmar.com/Fusion_files/Preliminary%20Engineering%20Venetian%20Blind.pdf| format = PDF|bibcode = 1974ITPS....2...71B }}</ref><ref name="Moir 1974 (b)">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0022-3115(74)90225-6| title = Surface requirements for electrostatic direct energy converters| journal = Journal of Nuclear Materials| volume = 53| pages = 86| year = 1974| last1 = Moir | first1 = R. W. | last2 = Barr | first2 = W. L. | last3 = Miley | first3 = G. H. | url = http://www.askmar.com/Fusion_files/Surface%20Requirements%20for%20Direct%20Energy%20Converters.pdf| format = PDF|bibcode = 1974JNuM...53...86M }}</ref>
William Barr and Ralph Moir then ran a group which did a series of direct energy conversion experiments through the late 1970s and early 1980s.<ref>Morris, Jeff. "In Memoriam." (n.d.): n. pag. Rpt. in Newsline. 19th ed. Vol. 29. Livermore: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, 2004. 2. Print.</ref> The first experiments used beams of positives and negatives as fuel, and demonstrated energy capture at a peak efficiency of 65 percent and a minimum efficiency of 50 percent.<ref name="Moir 1977 (a)">{{Cite conference |last1=Barr |first1=William L. |last2=Doggett |first2=James N. |last3=Hamilton |first3=Gordon W. |last4=Kinney |first4=John |last5=Moir |first5=Ralph W. |title=Engineering of Beam Direct Conversion for a 120kV, 1MW Ion Beam |date=25–28 October 1977 |conference=7th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research |location=Knoxville,Tennessee |url=http://www.askmar.com/Fusion_files/Beam%20Direct%20Conversion%20Engineering.pdf |format=PDF }}</ref><ref name="Moir 1982">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1007/BF01054580| title = Experimental results from a beam direct converter at 100 kV| journal = Journal of Fusion Energy| volume = 2| issue = 2| pages = 131| year = 1982| last1 = Barr | first1 = W. L.| last2 = Moir | first2 = R. W.| last3 = Hamilton | first3 = G. W.|bibcode = 1982JFuE....2..131B }}</ref> The following experiments involved a true plasma direct converter that was tested on the [[Tandem Mirror Experiment]] (TMX), an operating [[magnetic mirror]] fusion reactor. In the experiment, the plasma moved along diverging field lines, spreading it out and converting it into a forward moving beam with a [[Debye length]] of a few centimeters.<ref name="doi10.1088/0741-3335/36/8/003">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1088/0741-3335/36/8/003| title = Generic issues for direct conversion of fusion energy from alternative fuels| journal = Plasma Physics and Controlled Fusion| volume = 36| issue = 8| pages = 1255| year = 1994| last1 = Rosenbluth | first1 = M. N. | last2 = Hinton | first2 = F. L. |bibcode = 1994PPCF...36.1255R }}</ref> Suppressor grids then reflect the electrons, and collector anodes recovered the ion energy by slowing them down and collecting them at high-potential plates. This machine demonstrated an energy capture efficiency of 48 percent.<ref name="Moir 1983">{{Cite journal |last1=Barr |first1=William L. |last2=Moir |first2=Ralph W. |title=Test results on plasma direct converters |date=January 1983 |journal= |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=98–111 |publisher=American Nuclear Society |issn=0272-3921 }}</ref> However, [[Marshall Rosenbluth]] argued that keeping the plasma's neutral charge over the very short Debye length distance would be very challenging in practice, though he said that this problem would not occur in every version of this technology.<ref name="doi10.1088/0741-3335/36/8/003"/>
The Venetian Blind converter can operate with 100 to 150 keV D-T plasma, with an efficiency of about 60% under conditions compatible with economics, and an upper technical conversion efficiency up to 70% ignoring economic limitations.<ref name="Moir 1974 (a)" />
====Periodic electrostatic focusing==== A second type of electrostatic converter initially proposed by Post, then developed by Barr and Moir, is the Periodic Electrostatic Focusing concept.<ref name="Post 1969 (b)" /><ref name="Moir 1974 (b)" /><ref name="Moir 1977 (b)">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1109/TPS.1977.4317060| title = Computer Simulation of the Periodic Electrostatic Focusing Converter| journal = IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science| volume = 5| issue = 4| pages = 248| year = 1977| last1 = Barr | first1 = W. L.| last2 = Howard | first2 = B. C.| last3 = Moir | first3 = R. W.| url = http://www.askmar.com/Fusion_files/Periodic%20Electrostatic%20Focusing%20Converter.pdf| format = PDF|bibcode = 1977ITPS....5..248B }}</ref> Like the Venetian Blind concept, it is also a direct collector, but the collector plates are disposed in many stages along the longitudinal axis of an electrostatic focusing channel. As each ion is decelerated along the channel toward zero energy, the particle becomes "over-focused" and is deflected sideways from the beam, then collected. The Periodic Electrostatic Focusing converter typically operates with a 600 keV D-T plasma (as low as 400 keV and up to 800 keV) with efficiency of about 60% under conditions compatible with economics, and an upper technical conversion efficiency up to 90% ignoring economic limitations.<ref>{{Cite conference |last1=Smith |first1=Bobby H. |last2=Burleigh |first2=Richard |last3=Dexter |first3=Warren L. |last4=Reginato |first4=Lewis L. |title=An Engineering Study of the Electrical Design of a 1000-Megawatt Direct Converter for Mirror Reactors |conference=Texas Symposium on Technology of Controlled Thermonuclear Fusion Experiments and the Engineering Aspects of Fusion Reactors |location=Austin, Texas |date=20–22 November 1972 |publisher=U.S. Atomic Energy Commission }}</ref>
=== Induction systems ===
==== Conduction systems ==== {{main|Magnetohydrodynamic generator}} From the 1960s through the 1970s, methods have been developed to extract [[electrical energy]] directly from a hot gas (a [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]]) in motion within a channel fitted with [[electromagnet]]s (producing a transverse [[magnetic field]]), and [[electrode]]s (connected to load [[resistor]]s). [[Charge carrier]]s (free [[electron]]s and [[ion]]s) incoming with the flow are then separated by the [[Lorentz force]] and an [[Voltage|electric potential difference]] can be retrieved from pairs of connected electrodes. [[Shock tube]]s used as pulsed MHD generators were for example able to produce several [[Watt#Megawatt|megawatt]]s of [[electricity]] in channels the size of a [[beverage can]].<ref name="Sutton-Sherman">{{cite book |last1=Sutton |first1=George W. |last2=Sherman |first2=Arthur |title=Engineering Magnetohydrodynamics |publisher=Dover Publications |series=Dover Civil and Mechanical Engineering |date=July 2006 |isbn=978-0486450322}}</ref>
==== Induction systems ==== In addition to converters using electrodes, pure inductive magnetic converters have also been proposed by [[Lev Artsimovich]] in 1963,<ref name="Artsimovich 1963">{{Cite book |last=Artsimovich |first=L. A. |script-title=ru:Управляемые термоядерные реакции |language=Russian |trans-title=Controlled Thermonuclear Reactions |date=1963 |publisher=Fizmatgiz |location= Moscow |edition=2nd }}</ref> then Alan Frederic Haught and his team from United Aircraft Research Laboratories in 1970,<ref name="Haught 1970">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1063/1.1692870| title = Magnetic Field Confinement of Laser Irradiated Solid Particle Plasmas| journal = Physics of Fluids| volume = 13| issue = 11| pages = 2842| year = 1970| last1 = Haught | first1 = A. F. |bibcode = 1970PhFl...13.2842H }}</ref> and Ralph Moir in 1977.<ref name="Moir magnetic">{{Cite book |last=Moir |first=Ralph W. |editor-last= Considine |editor-first=Douglas M. |title=Energy Technology Handbook |chapter=Chapter 5: Direct Energy Conversion in Fusion Reactors |date=April 1977 |publisher=McGraw-Hill |location=NY |pages=150–154 |url=http://www.askmar.com/Fusion_files/Direct%20Energy%20Conversion%20in%20Fusion%20Reactors.pdf |format=PDF |isbn=978-0070124301 }}</ref>
The magnetic compression-expansion direct energy converter is analogous to the [[internal combustion engine]]. As the hot plasma expands against a [[magnetic field]], in a manner similar to hot gases expanding against a piston, part of the energy of the internal plasma is [[Electromagnetic induction|inductively]] converted to an [[electromagnetic coil]], as an [[Electromotive force|EMF]] ([[voltage]]) in the conductor.
This scheme is best used with pulsed devices, because the converter then works like a "magnetic [[four-stroke engine]]": # '''Compression''': A column of plasma is compressed by a magnetic field that acts like a piston. # '''Thermonuclear burn''': The compression heats the plasma to the thermonuclear ignition temperature. # '''Expansion/Power''': The expansion of fusion reaction products (charged particles) increases the plasma pressure and pushes the magnetic field outward. A voltage is induced and collected in the electromagnetic coil. # '''Exhaust/Refuel''': After expansion, the partially burned fuel is flushed out, and new fuel in the form of gas is introduced and ionized; and the cycle starts again.
In 1973, a team from [[Los Alamos National Laboratory|Los Alamos]] and [[Argonne National Laboratory|Argonne]] laboratories stated that the thermodynamic efficiency of the magnetic direct conversion cycle from [[alpha-particle]] energy to work is 62%.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1088/0029-5515/13/4/006| title = Direct conversion of thermonuclear plasma energy by high magnetic compression and expansion| journal = Nuclear Fusion| volume = 13| issue = 4| pages = 529| year = 1973| last1 = Oliphant | first1 = T. A. | last2 = Ribe | first2 = F. L. | last3 = Coultas | first3 = T. A. }}</ref>
=== Traveling-wave direct energy converter ===
In 1992, a Japan–U.S. joint-team proposed a novel direct energy conversion system for 14.7 MeV [[proton]]s produced by D-<sup>3</sup>He fusion reactions, whose energy is too high for electrostatic converters.<ref name="Momota 1992">{{Cite journal |last1=Momota |first1=Hiromu |last2=Ishida |first2=Akio |last3=Kohzaki |first3=Yasuji |last4=Miley |first4=George H. |last5=Ohi |first5=Shoichi |last6=Ohnishi |first6=Masami |last7=Sato |first7=Kunihiro |last8=Steinhauer |first8=Loren C. |last9=Tomita |first9=Yukihiro |last10=Tuszewski |first10=Michel |title=Conceptual Design of the D-3He Reactor Artemis |date=July 1992 |journal=Fusion Science and Technology |volume=21 |issue=4 |pages=2307–2323 |url=http://www.nifs.ac.jp/report/NIFS-101.pdf |format=PDF }}</ref>
The conversion is based on a Traveling-Wave Direct Energy Converter (TWDEC). A [[gyrotron]] converter first guides fusion product ions as a beam into a 10-meter long microwave cavity filled with a 10-tesla magnetic field, where 155 MHz microwaves are generated and converted to a high voltage DC output through [[rectenna]]s.
The [[Field-Reversed Configuration]] reactor ARTEMIS in this study was designed with an efficiency of 75%. The traveling-wave direct converter has a maximum projected efficiency of 90%.<ref name="Rostoker 1997">{{Cite journal|doi=10.1126/science.278.5342.1419 |pmid=9367946 |title=Colliding Beam Fusion Reactor |journal=Science |volume=278 |issue=5342 |pages=1419–22 |year=1997 |last1=Rostoker |first1=N. |last2=Binderbauer |first2=M. W. |last3=Monkhorst |first3=H. J. |url=http://fusion.ps.uci.edu/papers/cbfr-sci.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051220074004/http://fusion.ps.uci.edu/papers/cbfr-sci.pdf |archivedate=December 20, 2005 |bibcode = 1997Sci...278.1419R }}</ref>
===Inverse cyclotron converter (ICC)===
Original direct converters were designed to extract the energy carried by 100 to 800 keV ions produced by D-T fusion reactions. Those electrostatic converters are not suitable for higher energy product ions above 1 MeV generated by other fusion fuels like the D-<sup>3</sup>He or the ''p''-<sup>11</sup>B [[aneutronic fusion]] reactions.
A much shorter device than the Traveling-Wave Direct Energy Converter has been proposed in 1997 and patented by [[Tri Alpha Energy, Inc.]] as an Inverse [[Cyclotron]] Converter (ICC).<ref name="grant_2005">{{Cite patent |country=US |number=6850011 |status=patent |title=Controlled fusion in a field reversed configuration and direct energy conversion |gdate=2005-02-01 |fdate=2003-04-09 |pridate=2001-03-19 |invent1=Monkhorst, Hendrik J. |invent2=Rostoker, Norman |assign1=The Regents Of The University Of California |assign2=University Of Florida Research Foundation }}</ref><ref name="app_2006">{{Cite patent |country=WO |number=2006096772 |status=application |title=Plasma electric generation system |pubdate=2006-12-28 |fdate=2006-03-07 |pridate=2005-03-07 |invent1=Binderbauer, Michl |invent2=Bystritskii, Vitaly |invent3=Rostoker, Norman |invent4=Wessel, Franck |assign1=Binderbauer, Michl |assign2=Bystritskii, Vitaly |assign3=Rostoker, Norman |assign4=Wessel, Franck }}</ref>
The ICC is able to decelerate the incoming ions based on experiments made in 1950 by [[Felix Bloch]] and [[Carson D. Jeffries]],<ref name="Bloch">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1103/PhysRev.80.305| title = A Direct Determination of the Magnetic Moment of the Proton in Nuclear Magnetons| journal = Physical Review| volume = 80| issue = 2| pages = 305| year = 1950| last1 = Bloch | first1 = F.| last2 = Jeffries | first2 = C.|bibcode = 1950PhRv...80..305B }}</ref> in order to extract their kinetic energy. The converter operates at 5 MHz and requires a magnetic field of only 0.6 tesla. The [[linear motion]] of fusion product ions is converted to [[circular motion]] by a magnetic cusp. Energy is collected from the charged particles as they spiral past quadrupole electrodes. More classical electrostatic collectors would also be used for particles with energy less than 1 MeV. The Inverse Cyclotron Converter has a maximum projected efficiency of 90%.<ref name="Rostoker 1997" /><ref name="grant_2005"/><ref name="app_2006"/><ref name="Yoshikawa 1991">{{Cite journal |last1=Yoshikawa |first1=K. |last2=Noma |first2=T. |last3=Yamamoto |first3=Y. |title=Direct-Energy Conversion from High-Energy Ions Through Interaction with Electromagnetic Fields |date=May 1991 |journal=Fusion Science and Technology |publisher=American Nuclear Society |volume=19 |issue=3P2A |pages=870–875 |url=http://www.ans.org/store/j_29454 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite techreport |last1=Rostoker |first1=N. |last2=Binderbauer |first2=M. |last3=Monkhorst |first3=H. J. |title=Office of Naval Research Reports |year=1997 |issue=February 1997, May 1997, August 1997 }}</ref>
===X-ray photoelectric converter===
A significant amount of the energy released by fusion reactions is composed of [[electromagnetic radiation]]s, essentially [[X-ray]]s due to [[Bremsstrahlung]]. Those X-rays can not be converted into electric power with the various electrostatic and magnetic direct energy converters listed above, and their energy is lost.
Whereas more classical thermal conversion has been considered with the use of a radiation/boiler/energy exchanger where the X-ray energy is absorbed by a working fluid at temperatures of several thousand degrees,<ref>{{Cite book |last=Taussig |first=Robert T. |title=High thermal efficiency, radiation-based advanced fusion reactors |date=April 1977 |publisher=Electric Power Research Institute |location=Palo Alto, CA |url= http://www.worldcat.org/title/high-thermal-efficiency-radiation-based-advanced-fusion-reactors/oclc/123362448 }}</ref> more recent research done by companies developing nuclear aneutronic fusion reactors, like Lawrenceville Plasma Physics (LPP) with the [[Dense Plasma Focus]], and [[Tri Alpha Energy, Inc.]] with the Colliding Beam Fusion Reactor (CBFR), plan to harness the [[photoelectric effect|photoelectric]] and [[Auger effect|Auger]] effects to recover energy carried by X-rays and other high-energy [[photon]]s. Those photoelectric converters are composed of X-ray absorber and electron collector sheets nested concentrically in an onion-like array. Indeed, since X-rays can go through far greater thickness of material than electrons can, many layers are needed to absorb most of the X-rays. LPP announces an overall efficiency of 81% for the photoelectric conversion scheme.<ref name="LPP patent">{{Cite patent |country=US |number=7482607 |status=patent |title=Method and apparatus for producing X-rays, ion beams and nuclear fusion energy |gdate=2009-01-27 |fdate=2006-02-26 |pridate=2006-02-26 |invent1=Lerner, Eric J. |invent2=Blake, Aaron |assign1=Lawrenceville Plasma Physics, Inc. }}</ref><ref name="TAE patent">{{Cite patent |country=US |number=2013125963 |status=application |title=Conversion of high-energy photons into electricity |pubdate=2013-05-23 |fdate=2011-01-01 |pridate=2010-01-10 |invent1=Binderbauer, Michl |invent2=Tajima, Toshiki |assign1=Tri Alpha Energy, Inc. }}</ref>
== Direct energy conversion from fission products == {{Main article|Fission fragment reactor}} In the early 2000s, research was undertaken by [[Sandia National Laboratories]], [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]], [[The University of Florida]], [[Texas A&M University]] and [[General Atomics]] to use direct conversion to extract energy from fission reactions, essentially, attempting to extract energy from the linear motion of charged particles coming off a fission reaction.<ref name="Brown">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.2172/805252| title = Direct Energy Conversion Fission Reactor Annual Report for the Period August 15,2000 Through September 30,2001| year = 2002| last1 = l.c. Brown}}</ref>
== References ==
{{Reflist|30em}}
